text:
What was Lonely Island in your mind at the
time?
Like before we got SNL?

Yeah. We I mean, we were friends from junior
high and high school, first off, and then we,

you know, we started a website and we were
doing videos on our own and just trying to

get on. Um, so we had already started making
songs and videos and stuff, but it wasn't
like SNL, obviously.

It was like having videos on the internet
was new, where you'd be like, you can stream
a video. Yeah. You know.

Um, so we were like, we had had like two
pilots, like for, you know, attempts at TV
shows that were sketch shows.

Okay, that didn't go, but basically were
what we ended up doing on SNL.
So.
Probably should have.
Yeah, yeah. Let us make them.
Well, but here's my question, though.

How do you get the idea. Like what for you
guys early on?

Where do the concept of, you know, filming
the videos to put the videos on the internet
and hopefully get some bandwidth come from?

I mean, we were there was like, you know,
Stella, like those dudes from the state.

They had been doing their videos and we were
inspired by those.

Um, where it was like completely unhinged,
buck wild, like filthy.

So when we first started doing our videos,
we were like, oh, let's do stuff like them.

And then kind of by accident, we started
making the songs, you know, like we'd go out

at night and get drunk and come home and
like, record songs, sort of just for fun.

Okay. Um, and then at one point we were
like, let's do a video for one of those dumb
songs we did.

And as soon as we did, everyone we knew was
like, oh, that.
We like that.
That's the thing.

Yeah. So we were like, oh shit, okay, let's
keep doing them.

And then even when we got hired on SNL, it
was not to do that.

You know, we had been writing on the movie
awards for Fallon when he hosted, and we met

a lot of the people that worked at the show
there, and they were like, you should

audition. And even after we got hired, they
were still like, let's figure out how to do
your live stuff, Andy.

Like, let's find ways to introduce you to
the audience.

And then we kind of were like, oh, let's do
one of those songs.

And then the first one we did was Lazy
Sunday, and then they were just like, make
more of those, make more of the songs.
What did you guys see the next thing be?
I

mean, for me, specifically, my dream was SNL
from when I was like, really eight years old.
That's what I wanted.
So dope.

But I had no faith that that was going to
happen.
Why? Why was it your dream from eight?
Like. I just loved it.

I don't know why. I mean, I loved sketch in
general.

Okay. I would say like when I was in
elementary school and then junior high, I

watched SNL and In Living Color like that
was what I dined on.

And I would, like watch it once and memorize
it and regurgitate it for everyone at school

and like, do all the sketches for people,
for memory.

And, I don't know, I just it was like the
I've always really loved comedy where the
world can be almost like a cartoon.

Mhm. Um, and so that's why I loved like Mel
Brooks and Naked Gun and, you know, Monty
Python type stuff too.

Yeah. You're talking about, you're talking
about the cream of the crop.
But

surrealistic too, where it's like, oh,
wouldn't that be nice if the world, like,

wasn't so f***ing intense and you could
just, like, do whatever.

Yeah. You know what I mean? I was talking
about the there's a moment in Billy Madison

where Sandler's like, acting like a moron
and, like, grabs the dude's hand and just
starts biting it at the table.

You're like, what is happening in this
movie?

But for me, as a kid and as a teenager, I
was like, oh, f***, it's possible you can do

the thing that I like and actually have
people really see it.

Uh, when I'm most impressed about is you
talking about knowing what you wanted to do
from the age eight, right?

You having, uh, mindset to say, like, that's
that's the thing that I'm going to chase and
stick with. It is extremely impressive.
It's definitely, I think, a little rare.

I mean, a lot of kids are like, I want to be
on SNL, but at that time my parents would be

like, yeah, okay, yeah, like, I want to be
an astronaut.

You know, there's not that many people that
